name: Cades Cove Visitor Center
description: Roughly half-way through the Cades Cove Loop Road, pause to speak with park staff and visit various exhibits. Learn about Southern Mountain life and culture, and see a gristmill (operates spring through fall), the Becky Cable house, and other historic structures. Enjoy seasonal ranger-led activities and peruse the park bookstore and shop. Public restrooms available.

images.title: Front of Cades Cove Visitor Center
images.altText: A park visitor center built like a log cabin with a covered porch, chimney, and paved approach ramp.
images.caption: Roughly halfway around the Cades Cove Loop Road, this visitor center offers information, a park bookstore, and nearby restrooms.

images.title: Cades Cove Visitor Center
images.altText: Puzzles, DVDs, postcards, and other items displayed on shelves in a room with wood panel ceiling.
images.caption: Puzzles, DVDs, postcards, and other items are available for purchase at the park visitor centers.

images.title: Inside the Cades Cove Visitor Center
images.altText: Bookshelves and displays of key chains, postcards, and more by a fireplace with mugs on the mantel.
images.caption: Peruse park information and merchandise in the rustic Cades Cove Visitor Center.

images.title: Cades Cove Visitor Center
images.altText: Gravel path leading to the Cades Cove Visitor Center, a 19th century replica log cabin
images.caption: Cades Cove Visitor Center

images.title: View from Cades Cove Visitor Center
images.altText: A split rail fence by multiple walkways with two people walking towards buildings and trees.
images.caption: The Cades Cove Visitor Center is near other points of interest like Cable Mill, Becky Cable House, and more historic structures.

exceptions.name: Wednesdays from May to September (Vehicle-Free Days)

name: Kuwohi Visitor Center
description: Kuwohi (formerly Clingmans Dome) is the tallest peak in the Smokies. Enjoy sweeping views of the Smokies—weather permitting—and get your park questions answered. Peruse a small bookstore and shop. Public restrooms are available.

images.title: View approaching the Clingmans Dome Information Center and Store
images.altText: A sign that says "Clingmans Dome Information Center & Store" beside stairs near a brick building
images.caption: Stop by the Clingmans Dome Information Center to get your questions answered and peruse the park bookstore.

images.title: Inside the Clingmans Dome Information Center and Bookstore
images.altText: A small group of people observing bookshelves and displays in a park bookstore.
images.caption: Great Smoky Mountains Association, the park's nonprofit partner, sells a variety of items at the Clingmans Dome Information Center & Bookstore.

images.title: Outside the Clingmans Dome Information Center and Bookstore
images.altText: A building with exterior walls of various sized stones and a brown roof in front of evergreen trees.
images.caption: The Clingmans Dome Information Center & Bookstore is located at the beginning of the paved trail leading to the dome.

images.title: View on a clear day from Clingmans Dome parking lot
images.altText: Rolling blue mountains below a partly cloudy sky with grass, shrubs, and trees in the foreground.
images.caption: On a clear day, the Clingmans Dome parking lot offers a beautiful view.

images.title: Inside Clingmans Dome Bookstore
images.altText: Bookshelves and display structures with tshirts, stuffed animals, mugs, and other items for sale.
images.caption: Find the perfect souvenir at the Clingmans Dome Information Center & Bookstore.

operatingHours.description: Hours vary seasonally. Closed in winter.
operatingHours.name: Kuwohi Visitor Center

name: Oconaluftee Visitor Center
description: Near Cherokee, North Carolina, the Oconaluftee Visitor Center is an ideal starting point as you enter the park's South District. Explore cultural history exhibits. Enjoy ranger-led programs conducted seasonally. Peruse the park bookstore and shop. Find public restrooms and drink vending machines. The adjacent Mountain Farm Museum contains a collection of log structures including a farmhouse, barn, smokehouse, applehouse, corn crib and others.

images.title: Oconaluftee Visitor Center on a Sunny Day
images.altText: Grass and yellow flowers in front of a striking building with many windows, a porch, and a chimney.
images.caption: The Oconaluftee Visitor Center offers a shady porch for warm days.

images.title: Inside OVC
images.altText: A topographic map display in a room with large windows and a TV display plus park information
images.caption: The Oconaluftee Visitor Center's LEED-certified infrastructure provides wonderful natural light with its large windows.

images.title: View from OVC porch
images.altText: A porch railing overlooking a grassy field with mountains and trees in the distance
images.caption: The Oconaluftee Visitor Center porch can be a great spot to watch elk from a safe distance.

images.title: Bookstore at OVC
images.altText: Shelves and displays of merchandise like stuffed animals, books, postcards, clothes, and more.
images.caption: Find the perfect souvenir at the Oconaluftee Visitor Center's park bookstore.

images.title: OVC porch
images.altText: A covered porch area with a chimney, benches, and light fixtures on the ceiling.
images.caption: The porch at Oconaluftee Visitor Center offers a shaded resting spot for all.

images.title: Front of Oconaluftee Visitor Center
images.altText: The front of a building with many windows divided by brown frames beside gray brick siding.
images.caption: Large windows greet visitors to Oconaluftee Visitor Center

images.title: Information Displays at Oconaluftee Visitor Center
images.altText: Information panels about protecting park resources. Wooden and stone support beams in view.
images.caption: The park visitor centers offer opportunities for learning about the park and ways to protect it.

images.title: Oconaluftee Visitor Center
images.altText: Oconaluftee Visitor Center and administrative building adjacent to parking lot.
images.caption: Oconaluftee Visitor Center near Cherokee, NC

name: Sugarlands Visitor Center
description: Near Gatlinburg, TN, Sugarlands Visitor Center is an excellent starting point as you enter the park's North District. Learn about the park's plants and animals with natural history exhibits. Enjoy ranger-led programs conducted seasonally. Peruse the park bookstore and shop. Access public restrooms and drink vending machines. The Backcountry Permit Office is here, too.

images.title: Sugarlands Visitor Center in Early Spring
images.altText: The entrance area to a building, including grass, trees, benches, sidewalks, and enclosed gardens.
images.caption: Sugarlands Visitor Center offers seasonal ranger programs near the entrance area.

images.title: Sugarlands Visitor Center Front Desk
images.altText: A curved wooden welcome desk with a shiny top in front of a brick column with a colorful sign
images.caption: During visitor center hours, you will find helpful employees at the front desk to answer your questions.

images.title: Sugarlands Visitor Center Museum
images.altText: Entrance into the museum
images.caption: Millions have visited Sugarlands Visitor Center to view "Discover Life in the Smokies"

images.title: Sugarlands Visitor Center Bookstore
images.altText: Park patrons looking for the perfect souvenir
images.caption: You can't come to the Smokies and not get something to take home.

images.title: Sugarlands Visitor Center in Winter
images.altText: Building with a snowy roof on a cloudy day. The nearby pavement looks wet and people are approaching
images.caption: Great Smoky Mountains National Park receives winter snow, sometimes even at lower elevations.
